dialogues.text: He stumbles into a bird cage but hardly notices. The jost

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He runs into Bill on the front porch.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I've been looking for you. I have to take off again, real Chuck puts a hand on Bill's shoulder, stopping him. They

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuck walks out into the deep of his fields. The wheat, a furrow, powerless to think. The wind makes a song in the He puts his hands over his heart and breathes in gasps, w

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Late that afternoon disaster strikes as a swarm of locust

dialogues.speaker: ANIMALS ON BONANZA
dialogues.text: The animals sense it first. The buffalo move off in a mas Two peacocks have a fight. A dog in the treadmill races in vain to escape, driving t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything seems normal in the fields. Then, as you listen, a strange new sound begins to rise f

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT ON LOCUSTS
dialogues.text: Suddenly we see them up close, devouring the stalks in a They slip into the Belvedere, under the sash and wainscot

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their eyes are dumb and implacable. They seem to have a w

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little by little they gather in numbers. Ursula first see is too slow. She begins to use her fingers. She moves wit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the bedroom overhead, Abby wakes up from one nightmare

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly they are everywhere: on the clothesline, in the

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT ON CHUCK
dialogues.text: Chuck, asleep in the deep of the wheat, bolts up in slow

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Panic hits the bonanza. Workers tie string around their p other noisemakers to scare them off. Some pray. Others run around like madmen, stamping and ye A storm flag is run up the flagpole. A tractor blasts out

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT ON CHUCK
dialogues.text: Chuck gives Benson his orders.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: Offer fifty cents a bushel for them. Get out the reapers. See what you can harvest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The locusts snap through the air. Bill, swatting at them

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT ON GEARS
dialogues.text: They jam up the gears of the machinery with the crush of

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abby throws a sheet over herself, but they get in under i

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK AND BENSON
dialogues.text: Benson reports back to Chuck. A team of horses races by,

dialogues.speaker: BENSON
dialogues.text: We can't get the machines out. They're jamming up the gea There's a good chance they'll pass on south, though. Unle unless a wind comes up.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: What happens then?

dialogues.speaker: BENSON
dialogues.text: They'll set down and walk in.

dialogues.speaker: SIGNS OF DAMAGE
dialogues.text: The locusts devour not just the crops but every organic t Bill looks away from a tree for a second. When he turns b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The vanes of the wind generator begin gently to stir. Lit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the sun dips below the horizon, the locusts pour in li

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And these are but the advance elements of a main force wh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WORKERS dump bushels of the insects into a bonfire. A MAN

dialogues.speaker: SAME FIELDS
dialogues.text: The wind has picked up. Chuck, Bill and Abby have come ou

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT ON CHUCK
dialogues.text: Chuck inspects the grain.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: There's nothing we can do but wait. They're either going He covers his face with his hands. The others shy back at Bill, moved to real sympathy, takes him by the shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Come on. They might still lift. Hey, I've seen a wind lik down and die. Don't give up now.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: (ignoring him) We could at least make sure they don't get the people on He breaks open the mantle of his lantern, still unsure wh

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: What're you doing? Watch it! What're you, crazy? There's still a chance, don't you see? Chuck goes to his horse. Bill grabs him by the sleeve. Do

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Stop him, or it's all going up. They, however, are too uncertain of their ground to inter

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: What does it matter to you? Chuck slings fire out of the broken lantern onto the crop He slings the fire out again. A patch lands on Bill's pan

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: What's got into you? They stare at each other. Bill backs off like a cat, sens

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: Why do you care? I gave my life for this land. Chuck walks towards him. Suddenly Bill turns and takes of The whirr of the locusts stops for a moment--they seem at

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Stop, Chuck! Chuck leaps on his horse. She tries to drag him off but i

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Bill runs through the night, still carrying his lantern. Bill realizes the lantern is giving his position away He

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a rough idea where Bill is, Chuck begins to lay a ri

dialogues.speaker: BILL AND ABBY INSIDE RING
dialogues.text: Abby spots Bill against the flames. She rushes up, gaspin

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: What're you doing? This is a bad place to talk He throws his coat over Abby's head, picks her up by the

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Did you see that? He was trying to burn me. What's got in

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: He knows. He must.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: A whole year's work. All wasted! These bugs, once they ma their minds... Bill stalls. The fire races toward them through the wheat

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I need to get out of here. I think you probably should, t (pause) Hell of a life. Damned if you do and damned if you don't. He leaves. Abby wonders if she ought to run after him.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Bill! But this moment's hesitation has been too long. Already h them. Abby turns back. She, too, has reason to fear Chuck and m

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Benson rallies the workers.

dialogues.speaker: BENSON
dialogues.text: There's still a chance they're going to fly.

dialogues.speaker: VOICES
dialogues.text: Get the tractor out! The pump wagon! Blankets! They rush off to find equipment to fight the fire.

dialogues.speaker: ISOLATED ON CHUCK
dialogues.text: Chuck rides through the dark like a lone Horseman of the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tractors attempt to plow a firebreak. Mad silhouettes run Ursula throws open the barn and lets the horses out. They

dialogues.speaker: EXPLOSIONS
dialogues.text: Oil wells explode along the horizon. Huge balls of flames

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Panic spreads among the workers as the holocaust threaten

dialogues.speaker: ANIMALS
dialogues.text: Animals flee in all directions:  birds and deer and rabbi

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Bill, fleeing on his motorbike with his rabbit, holds up for a moment to watch the fire--a Biblical inferno of spe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A single light burns in the Belvedere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heaving with sobs, Abby throws her things into a bindle. denly Chuck steps from the shadows, blocking her exit. His face, black with soot, looks gruesome in the gas1ight Abby is like a frightened deer. Did he see her packing?

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: You look as though you'd seen a ghost. (pause) Where you going? (pause) Off with him? The wind cuts gaps in the death wail of the locusts. From

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: He's not your brother, is he? How much does he know? She edges toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Why do you say that?

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: Come here a minute. Who are you? (no reply) Where'd you come from?

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: I told you. He shakes her. She quivers like a child in his grasp. She

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: How long have you known? He drops his eyes. Shamefully long -- and his anger is pa

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: What'd you want? He punches in the shade of a lamp, extin

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: Tell me. He shoves over the chest of drawers. She does no He tears down the drapes, already in shreds.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: This? Show me what you wanted! I would have given it all

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Please, Chuck.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: Please what? You're not going to tell me you're sorry, I

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: But I am. Outside the window fires rage along half the horizon. He

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: You're so wonderful. How could you do this?

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: I'm just no good. You picked me from the gutter, and this how -- I never deserved you.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: (interrupting) The things you told me.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: I love you, though. You have to believe me. It may sound

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Down at the cave. Don't you remember? I believed them.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: All right. I'm going away. You'll never have to see me ag

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: Away? He gets up, suddenly alarmed, walks to the mantel and ope

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: What're you doing? Chuck drapes his neck with the stole he used in slaughter

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abby pursues him down the stairs. He throws her aside.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Where are you doing? Chuck! What are you doing? I won't   let you! Come back! Again he throws her aside, and again she keeps after him,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lashes her with a rope to a column of the porch. She s

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: No, Chuck! Please, darling! It wasn't his fault. It was m Let him go. I love you, Chuck. Do anything, only please..

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: I'm sick of hearing lies.   He stuffs a handkerchief in her mouth and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT ON CHUCK
dialogues.text: Chuck wanders through the night with a lantern, calling h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dawn breaks. Chuck rides over the burnt-out fields lookin making a sound, wreathed in a mist of blue smoke. With hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burnt, blind deer stand and look at him in utter terror, A peacock from the Belvedere wanders around, angry and perplexed.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Bill is repairing his motorbike by a rock in the middle o He jumps behind the handlebars and fishtails off. Chuck b

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Who do you think you are? Now you've ruined it. What's go into you?

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: Where you headed?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Why do I have to tell you? I can come and go when I like. This is still a free country, last I heard. Bill stops when he sees the stool. Chuck calmly strops th

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: What can I say? Too late for apologies. You've got a righ to hate me. Chuck puts the razor away and advances on Bill with the s

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I want to leave. You won't ever see me again. I already g I deserve. There is nothing Bill can say to appease him. This will b

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Watch it! Chuck comes at him again. Bill throws a punch, but Chuck Bill reels back and cracks his head on the bicycle frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuck shuts his eyes to mumble a prayer of absolution--in Bill in a panic, snaps a spoke out of the broken wheel an Chuck moves in for the kill. Bill gets to his feet. He wa drives it deep into Chuck's heart. Chuck gasps. Bill seems just as shocked. Chuck sits down

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Should I pull it out? Chuck puts his finger over the end of the spoke. Blood se

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I better get somebody. He tries to catch the reins of Chuck's horse, but it shie

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: You were my friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Belvedere is visible on the horizon. Bill hesitates a moment, then heads back on foot to find Abby. He gives Chuck a wide berth. Then, on a ridge in the distance, he spots Benson.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Get a doctor! Fast! How much did he see? Bill does not stay to find out but takes off running, though not without first collecting hi rabbit. Benson, meanwhile, bounds down the hill to Chuck's side. His left sleeve has been burned away. The flesh beneath is the color of a raw steak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuck sees the smoke from his fields, the burnt deer, a circling hawk.

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT ON CHUCK
dialogues.text: He breathes in gulps. His eyes are blank, like a child's marbles. He takes Benson's hand.

dialogues.speaker: CHUCK
dialogues.text: (weakly) Wasn't his fault. Tell her...forgive them. The locusts can be heard no more. The prairie makes a sound like the ocean. Chuck turns his back and dies.

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT ON BENSON
dialogues.text: Benson weeps. Whether or not he understood Chuck's last wishes, he seems unlikely to abide by them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill finds Abby bound to the house like the figurehead of a ship. He cuts her loose. The ropes fall at her feet. They look at each other for a moment. Then, in a rush of compassion for them all, she throws her arms around him. Bill wonders if she is taking him back. Might their differences all have been a terrible misunderstanding?

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: We have to hurry. Chuck's out looking right now. Oh, Bill what have we done? He took his razor. We need to hurry. H might be coming back any minute. Bill mentions nothing of his encounter. She grabs her bindle, Bill a handful of silverware and an umbrella. After a moment's hesitation, he puts them back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They run down to the barn, where the cars are stored. The saplings in the front yard have been stripped even of their bark. Abby stops to look back at the Belvedere one last time. Chuck does not want her anymore. How could she expect him to? Bill grabs her by the hand and tugs her along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abby throws open the doors of the barn. Bill cranks up the engine of the Overland.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Will the cops be looking for us, too?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Probably. Abby stands in the door. She is reluctant to leave, thoug knows they must.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Get in. She notices that Bill's lip is cut, his shirt soaked with blood.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: What happened to you? Where's this from? Bill looks down. He forgot.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Had an accident. She looks at him for a moment, not quite trusting this explanation. The engine catches with a noise like start- led poultry. Bill gets behind the wheel. Just as they are pulling out of the garage, Ursula runs up, black  as coal from battling the fire all night.

dialogues.speaker: URSULA
dialogues.text: Where you going?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: (breathless) We got in a jam. You'll be safer here. Say we're headed f Take care of the rabbit, too. He's yours now.

dialogues.speaker: URSULA
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Just do what I say. Why're you always arguing about every Wait here till we get in touch. Bill gives Ursula his wallet and a kiss. Abby gives her a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They roar off through the burnt grass of the prairie. Abby waves goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they crest a ridge, Benson appears in front of them, waving a hand to flag them down. Bill puts his foot on the gas. Benson sees they are not going to stop and fires at then with a pistol. Bill grabs a shotgun from a scab- bard under the dash and fires back. Nobody is hurt.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: What's the matter with him? Bill shrugs. Inside he feels a great relief. They are free at last. At last he has her back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They veer off across the prairie, towards the Razumihin gates. The music comes up full.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They have come to a lone shack on the river, a drinking house for passing boatmen. They negotiate (in pantomime) with the PROPRIETOR for a tiny steam boat moored at the end of the pier. When the car is not enough, Abby throws in her necklace.

dialogues.speaker: ABOARD THE BOAT
dialogues.text: They board the boat and turn down stream. There is a phon on board.

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT ON NECKLACE
dialogues.text: The necklace sparkles on the hood of the car--a hint they are leaving behind evidence that could betray them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They glide along in the hush of evening. The reeds are full of deer. Cranes, imprudently tame, dance on the sand bars. Bill looks around in wonder. He knows these may be his last days on earth. Abby throws a sounding line. A COUPLE from a local farm seeks privacy in the willows. Other BOATMEN glide past in silence. A CHILD plays a fiddle on the deck of a scow. HUNTERS creep along the shore in search of waterfowl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill sleeps under a tarp. Abby looks out across the water and bursts into sobs. She has wronged Chuck and thrown her life away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They shine a lamp into the murky depths and spear pickere with a hammered-out fork. Strange rocks loom up and give way to wide moonlit fields They have the sense of entering places where nobody has been since the making of the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four LAWMEN, in pursuit, interrogate some FARMERS. Have they seen the two people standing by Chuck in his wedding portrait? Benson holds the bulky frame. There is a funere border of black crepe at the corners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They drift idly on the flood. The phonograph is playing in the stern. Abby is back in trousers. Bill points to a white house on the shore, an image of comfort and peace

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I used to want a set-up like that. Something like that, I and you'd really have it made. Now I don't care. I just w we could always live this way. He sees that her mind is somewhere else. He wants to tell her the truth about Chuck, for intimacy's sake, but it would just put more of a cloud over everything. It might even cause her to hate him.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Maybe you want to write him a  letter.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: I hadn't thought of that.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: You really do love him, don't you? She does not reply.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: You want to go back?

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: (shaking her head) Too late for that. I could never face him again. They look at each other for a moment. He touches her face to show that he does not hold it against her. She touches him back. They only have each other now. They must save what moments they can.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Guess it's you and me again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a sudden whim, Abby takes off her wedding bracelet and holds it over the water.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Watch this. Bill is caught off guard. Before he can make a move she throws it far out into the river. They laugh, without knowing why, at this extravagance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They gather May apples and black haws. The music from the phonograph comes up full. They dig clams from a sand bar in a playful way. We are reminded of their first days on the harvest.

dialogues.speaker: XT. UNDERGROWTH
dialogues.text: They make love in the undergrowth. Abby, afterwards, lies in a naked daze. The damp greens of the wilderness envelop her.

dialogues.speaker: ON CITY ON RIVER
dialogues.text: Rounding a bend in the river that night, they come upon the lights of a great city. They have doused the running lamp. Except for a faint groaning of the trees along the shore, the river is silent, conveying the sounds of the city to them from across a great distance -- bells, joy- ful voices, horns, the chirping of brakes, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sneak down an alley. There are signs of life behind a few windows, but the city pursues its gaiety elsewhere. Suddenly, they come upon a POLICEMAN making his rounds. They let him pass, then cut through a vacant lot back to the boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next morning finds them camped in a thicket on the ri front below a factory. Bill wakes up, mysteriously happy. Their blankets are hea with dew. Overhead, finches tilt from branch to branch. A light wind rushes through the leaves. Whatever his trou- bles, they seem very small to him in the great. scheme of things. He looks at Abby, mouthing silent words in her sleep. He puts on a white scarf and starts down to the boat. The slope is strewn with sodden cartons, burnt bricks and bur mattresses, an avalanche of urban excreta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abruptly he stops. Two POLICE OFFICERS are combing over t boat. They have not seen him. He edges back. Suddenly, th a rabbit into the thicket.

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT ON ABBY
dialogues.text: Abby bolts awake. Bill jumps down beside her, breathless, and begins looking frantically for the shells to his shot

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Keep down. Can't explain now. They're here.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Who? What're you talking about?  Stop a minute. He covers her with his body as bullets zoom through the undergrowth. His face is close to hers. She bursts into tears.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Don't get shot. Look for me under that next bridge down.  After dark. He empties out the contents of his pockets -- a watch, a couple of dollars in change, a ring -- and slaps them dow in front of her. The Police fan out along the ridge above them. He jams a flare pistol into his belt and kisses her goodbye--after a moment's hesitation -- on the cheek. She tries in vain to hold him back.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I wish I could tell you how much I love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill runs from the thicket down to the water. The Police have bunched on the other side. It seems he might be able to escape. Keeping low, he splashes across a mud flat. Suddenly he runs into a trot line that a fisherman has left out overnight. The hooks bite into his thigh and shoulder, yanking a string of startled, thrashing catfish out of the water. He keeps running in a panic, not realizing the line is staked to the shore. All at once, he jackknifes in the air. The stake twangs loose. The Police now spot him  and begin firing.

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT ON ABBY
dialogues.text: Abby runs out of hiding, thinking at first that the Polic must be looking for her.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Why're you shooting? You'll kill him! Have you gone crazy Stop! Oh, Bill, not you! Not you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill stumbles along, trying to rip the hooks from his flesh, but the fish--fighting their way back to the water--only drive them in deeper. Ahead two MOUNTED POLICE surge into the river, blocking his retreat. He empties his shotgun at them and throws it away. They hold up, astonished. He dashes across a sand bar for the deep of the river and comparative safety. Black mud cling to his feet, drawing him down like a fly in molasses. Benson goes running out into the river ahead of the Polic

dialogues.speaker: BENSON
dialogues.text: Leave him alone. I want him. Leave him alone. (firing) There you go! There you go! He shoots Bill down. Bill turns and looks at him in sur- prise. Benson shoots him again, point blank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill's blood fades off quickly in the gliding water of th river. The line of frightened catfish dances out behind him like a garland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dog trots off in alarm. Benson wades into shore, tears streaming down his face, his chest heaving with emotion. Abby falls to the ground in a convulsion of grief. A short way down the river PEOPLE come and go along the bridge where they were to meet.

dialogues.speaker: ISOLATED ON ROLLER PIANO
dialogues.text: A roller piano sits in a corner by itself, playing a fox- trot. The camera moves back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG DANCERS are learning the foxtrot in the attic of th Arboretum, a tacky Western version of an Eastern finishin school. The steps are painted on the floor as white footp Abby is apparently enrolling Ursula here. The headmistres MADAME MURPHY, boasts of the school's achievements.  Ursula looks trapped. Abby checks her watch. She must go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abby and Ursula walk down an empty street. Abby wears a mourning band on her sleeve. She is under the false im- pression that Ursula likes her new home. An INDIAN PORTER carts her bags along behind them in a wheelbarrow.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: They'll teach you poise, too, so you can walk in any room please. Pretty soon you'll know all kind of things. (pause) I never read a whole book till I was fifteen. It was by C They laugh at her careful pronunciation of "Caesar."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abby's train is about to leave. The CONDUCTOR walks by blowing a whistle. A five-piece BAND plays Sousa airs. They are practically the only civilians on the platform. The rest are SOLDIERS bound for Europe, where America has just entered the War, on fire with excitement and a sense of high adventure.

dialogues.speaker: URSULA
dialogues.text: I like your hat.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: It doesn't seem like a bird came down and landed on my he Abby takes the hat off and gives it to Ursula, who lately has begun to take more trouble with her appearance, comb- ing her hair free of its usual snarls. They laugh at thei in a window of the train.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: I hardly ever wear it. Be sure and write every week. Signals nod. A lamp winks. There are leave-takings up and down the platform as the train slides away. Abby hops on board. A SOLDIER next to her sheds bitter tears.

dialogues.speaker: URSULA
dialogues.text: You write me, too! They wave goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Late that evening Ursula lowers herself out a third-floor window of the Arboretum with a rope made of bedsheets.

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT ON GIRLS AT WINDOW
dialogues.text: The other GIRLS stand in their nightgowns and wave good- bye, amazed at her boldness. She slips off into the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ursula looks in a backstage door. She can see, through the wings, a MAN dancing on stage. There is a feeling of mad excitement about the place. The person she is looking for is not here, however.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She runs down an alley. A man steps out of the shadows-- George, the pilot. She throws herself in his arms. This is our first sight of him since he left the bonanza.

dialogues.speaker: URSULA
dialogues.text: You're here! Oh, hug me! They kiss madly, with mystery. The moonlit, midsummer nig

dialogues.speaker: URSULA
dialogues.text: Aren't we happy? Oh, George, has anybody ever been this h He rocks her back and forth in his arms. They laugh, thinking what lucky exceptions they are to the world's misery.

dialogues.speaker: URSULA
dialogues.text: Hurry.  They'll be looking for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George bundles Ursula, giggling, into a biplane.

dialogues.speaker: URSULA
dialogues.text: This doesn't even belong to you. Suppose they catch us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From a pasture outside town the plane rises into the vast

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abby changes bobbins on a huge loom. A pall of lint and anonymous toil hangs over the factory. Down the way a handsome MALE WORKER smiles at her. She smiles back, interested.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: It seems an age we've been apart, and truly is for those love each other so. Whenever shall we meet?'

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT ON MACHINERY
dialogues.text: The shuttle rockets back and forth. Off camera we hear Abby reading what seems part of a letter to Ursula. ABBY (o.s.) Soon, I hope, for by and by we'll all be gone, Urs. Does it really seem as though we might?'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We look from the bottom of a river up toward the light.  In the foreground, dangling from the tip of a submerged limb, is the bracelet Abby threw away. ABBY (o.s.) 'The other day I tried to think how I'd look laid out in white gown. Closing my eyes I could almost hear you tipto

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PEOPLE of the Razumihin rebuild the land -- raising fences and sinking a well, plowing down the stubble and putting in the seed. ABBY (o.s.) 'I went to Lincoln Park Zoo the other day. It was great a I enclose a check.' An ANONYMOUS YOUNG MAN, standing on a carpet  of new-sprung wheat, looks up with a start. From the  distance comes a ghostly noise--the call of the prairie  chickens at their spring rites. He listens for just a mom then returns to work.
